name: Ollie
description: The foundation of street skating. Pop the tail while sliding your front foot up to level out the board in the air.
tips: Start stationary before trying while rolling
Slide your front foot — don't just jump
Timing the pop and slide is everything

name: Kickflip
description: An ollie with a flick off the heelside edge of the nose, causing the board to flip 360° along its length.
tips: Front foot angled slightly off the edge
Flick is subtle — more ankle than leg
Catch it with your back foot first

name: Heelflip
description: Like a kickflip but flicked with the heel off the toeside edge, rotating the board the opposite direction.
tips: Toes hang off the toeside edge
Push out with your heel
Keep shoulders square over the board

name: Pop Shove-It
description: The board rotates 180° beneath you (backside) while you stay facing the same direction.
tips: Scoop the tail backward with your back foot
Keep your weight centered
Don't jump too high — let the board spin under you

name: Frontside Pop Shove-It
description: The board rotates 180° frontside beneath you. Opposite rotation of a regular (backside) pop shove-it.
tips: Push the tail forward instead of scooping back
Front foot guides the catch
Easier if you lean slightly forward

name: 360 Flip (Tre Flip)
description: A combination of a kickflip and a 360 pop shove-it. The board flips and rotates 360° simultaneously. One of the most iconic tricks in skateboarding.
tips: Back foot does most of the work — big scoop
Front foot flicks lightly
Let it come to you; don't chase it

name: Varial Kickflip
description: A kickflip combined with a backside pop shove-it. The board flips and rotates 180° simultaneously.
tips: Less scoop than a tre flip
Keep your flick consistent
Catch with back foot

name: Varial Heelflip
description: A heelflip combined with a frontside pop shove-it.
tips: Front foot flicks heel while back foot scoops frontside
Keep centered
Timing is everything

name: Hardflip
description: A kickflip combined with a frontside pop shove-it. The board flips vertically between your legs.
tips: The board goes between your legs — commit
Strong frontside scoop
Catch it early

name: Inward Heelflip
description: A heelflip combined with a backside pop shove-it. The board flips inward between your legs.
tips: Scoop backside while flicking heel
Board comes inward — watch your shins
Commit fully

name: Backside 180
description: An ollie with a 180° backside rotation of both you and the board.
tips: Wind up your shoulders before popping
Head turns first, body follows
Land rolling switch

name: Frontside 180
description: An ollie with a 180° frontside rotation. You and the board turn frontside together.
tips: Look over your front shoulder
Lead with your upper body
Spot your landing

name: Backside Boardslide
description: Ollie onto a rail or ledge and slide with the middle of the board perpendicular to the obstacle.
tips: Turn 90° and center your weight over the rail
Keep your knees bent
Turn out at the end — don't hang up

name: 50-50 Grind
description: Ollie onto a rail or ledge and grind with both trucks locked on.
tips: Approach parallel to the obstacle
Lock both trucks on simultaneously
Lean slightly toward the obstacle

name: 5-0 Grind
description: A grind on only the back truck, like a manual on a rail or ledge.
tips: Keep your weight over the back truck
Don't lean too far back or you'll slip out
Pop off at the end

name: Nosegrind
description: A grind on only the front truck. Requires precise weight distribution and commitment.
tips: Lean forward and lock the front truck
Keep the tail up
Nollie out or turn 90° to dismount

name: Smith Grind
description: Back truck grinds with the board angled down below the obstacle. Front truck hangs below the ledge/rail.
tips: Approach at a slight angle
Dip the nose below the ledge
Pop out cleanly to avoid hang-ups

name: Feeble Grind
description: Back truck grinds with the board going over the obstacle. The opposite of a smith grind.
tips: Ollie high enough to clear the rail with your front truck
Lock the back truck and lean in
Commit — half-attempts are dangerous

name: Crooked Grind
description: A nosegrind with the board angled, nose pinching the edge of the ledge.
tips: Angle your approach slightly
Lock the nose at an angle
Wax helps

name: Kickflip Backside Tailslide
description: Kickflip into a backside tailslide on a ledge. A high-level combination trick requiring precision and commitment.
tips: Master both tricks independently first
Flip early and catch before locking in
Full commitment required

name: Drop In
description: Standing at the top of a ramp or bowl, place your tail on the coping and lean forward to roll in.
tips: Commit — leaning back = slamming
Stomp your front foot and lean in
Start on small ramps

name: Rock to Fakie
description: Roll up a ramp, let your front trucks go over the coping, then rock back and roll down fakie.
tips: Don't go too far over — just past the coping
Lift the front slightly to clear the coping on the way back
Keep weight centered

name: Axle Stall
description: Ride up and stall with both trucks on the coping, then drop back in.
tips: Turn 90° at the top
Set both trucks on the coping
Lean in to drop back

name: Blunt to Fakie
description: Ride up, pop the tail over the coping so the board is vertical on the deck, then pop back in fakie.
tips: Pop hard to get the tail over
Balance point is critical
Snap back in quickly

name: Manual
description: Rolling on only the back two wheels — a wheelie on a skateboard.
tips: Find the balance point
Use your arms for micro-adjustments
Look ahead, not at your feet

name: Nose Manual
description: Rolling on only the front two wheels. Harder than a regular manual due to weight distribution.
tips: Lean forward but don't nosedive
Shift weight over the front bolts
Arms out for balance

name: Impossible
description: The board wraps vertically around your back foot in a full 360° rotation.
tips: Scoop straight down and wrap it around your foot
Keep it vertical — a flat impossible isn't an impossible
Back foot does all the work

name: Laser Flip
description: A heelflip combined with a 360 frontside pop shove-it. The inverse of a tre flip.
tips: Strong frontside scoop with the back foot
Heel flick needs perfect timing
One of the hardest flat tricks — patience

name: Nollie
description: An ollie popped from the nose instead of the tail. Front foot pops, back foot slides.
tips: Mirror your ollie technique
Pop the nose with your front foot
Slide your back foot toward the tail

name: Switch Ollie
description: An ollie performed in switch stance (riding opposite your natural stance).
tips: Practice riding switch first
Everything feels backwards — be patient
Your 'weak' foot needs to learn to pop
